Title: Ramsey goodness of cycles
Abstract: © 2020 Society for Industrial and Applied MathematicsGiven a pair of graphs G and H, the Ramsey number R(G,H) is the smallest N such that every red-blue coloring of the edges of the complete graph KN contains a red copy of G or a blue copy of H. If a graph G is connected, it is well known and easy to show that R(G,H) ≥ (| G| - 1)(χ (H) - 1) + σ (H), where χ (H) is the chromatic number of H and σ (H) is the size of the smallest color class in a χ (H)-coloring of H. A graph G is called H-good if R(G,H) = (| G| - 1)(χ (H) - 1)+σ (H). The notion of Ramsey goodness was introduced by Burr and Erdös in 1983 and has been extensively studied since then. In this paper we show that if n ≥ 1060| H| and σ (H) ≥ χ (H)22, then the n-vertex cycle Cn is H-good. For graphs H with high χ (H) and σ (H), this proves in a strong form a conjecture of Allen, Brightwell, and Skokan.
